proposals.reasoning: This matches the emerging table consensus and keeps the opener relatively low‑risk without immediately locking in a Bob+Diana core. Diana felt like a steady anchor last game, and pairing her with Alice gives us a clean early read on two active talkers while still leaving Bob off the first mission so we can evaluate him separately based on how this one goes and on later discussion. It balances early information gain with not concentrating too much trust on a single pair right away.

votes.comment: I’m on the team with a broadly trusted player, and Mission 1 is usually worth running for early info unless there’s a strong reason not to, which we don’t have yet.
Reasonable low-risk opener with no known evil; good info either way and matches table consensus without over-shaping early teams.
Fits my earlier preference for Alice+Diana; solid low-risk opener without overlocking a Bob+Diana core.
I’d rather start with Bob+Diana as a cleaner baseline; pairing with Alice feels higher-risk given alternatives.
Fits table consensus and avoids early suspicion for blocking a widely supported low-risk opener.
This matches what I said I preferred (Alice+Diana) and avoids locking in a Bob+Diana core too early while still giving us useful early info.
I already voiced support for Alice+Diana as a balanced, low-risk opener and don’t see a strong reason to deviate from that early consensus.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather keep it simple and low‑info: I’m fine with me plus someone who felt reliably good last game, like Bob or Diana, so we get an early baseline to read from.

I’m okay keeping it simple, but I’d slightly prefer Diana on the first mission since she felt pretty steady last game, whether that’s Alice+Diana or Diana+me. Early on I’d rather avoid pulling in the quieter wild cards until we’ve seen a bit more table talk.

I like starting with Diana plus one of Bob/Alice—Diana felt very steady last game, and an Alice+Diana team gives us a nice clean early read without stacking too many “trusted” talkers together. If I had to pick right now, I’d lean Alice+Diana.

I’m fine being on the first mission, but given last game’s shaky start with Alice I’d slightly rather pair with Bob this time for a cleaner baseline. If the table really prefers Alice+Diana I won’t block it, but I think Diana+Bob is the lower‑risk opener.
Diana+Bob seems like a solid low‑drama opener to me—if it passes clean we’ve got a pretty trustworthy core to build from, and if it doesn’t we get immediate, high‑value info.
I’d slightly rather avoid locking in a Bob+Diana core this early—Alice+Diana feels like a good compromise that still uses a “steady” player but doesn’t cluster all the trust on two people right away.
I’d also rather not lock in a Bob+Diana core right away—Alice+Diana feels like a good first test, and we can reassess how we feel about Bob after we see how this one goes.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and me (Diana) was clean, which at least makes us a reasonable core for now; while that doesn’t hard-clear either of us, it’s the lowest-risk anchor we have. For the third slot, I prefer Bob because he’s been consistently advocating a tight, low-variance team that keeps the proven Mission 1 pair and adds one informed, vocal player. That matches how a cautious good player tends to behave, whereas Eve/Frank/Grace are all pushing more aggressively for ‘information-gathering’ lineups, which can be more attractive for evil this early. Adding Bob both aligns with my previously stated preference and keeps the team compact and defensible if this mission succeeds.

votes.comment: Mission 1’s Alice–Diana pair is our best anchor so far; adding just one new player (Bob) is a low-variance, informative test, and a fail here tightly narrows suspicion to Bob/Diana rather than spreading it wide.
Team excludes both known evils (Eve, Grace), keeps the clean Mission 1 core plus me, which is the safest low-variance option right now.

Alice+Diana from a clean Mission 1 is our best core so far, and adding Bob—who’s been playing a cautious, structured game—looks safer than pivoting to the ‘info-gathering’ lineups that Eve/Frank/Grace are pushing this early.
Mission 1’s Alice+Diana core is our best info so far, and adding Bob is a tight, low-variance choice; if it fails we get strong alignment info on Alice/Bob, so this is both safe and informative.

Keeping Alice and Diana makes sense, but adding Bob just reinforces a tight circle without giving us new info. I’d rather see a lineup that tests at least one of Eve/Frank/Grace so we don’t go into Mission 3 with the same blind spots.
I’d rather not lock in the same core plus Bob this early; adding someone new (like me or Eve/Grace) would give more information and avoid a tight circle forming around the Mission 1 pair.
Team is a natural extension of the clean Mission 1 core and looks reasonable to most players; rejecting it without strong reason would be more suspicious than helpful right now.

discussion.content: I know I’m good, and Diana looks decent after that clean first mission, so I’d lean toward keeping both of us on the next team and adding whoever feels most consistently pro-good in their voting so far.
Sticking with Alice and Diana feels like the safest anchor right now, and adding Charlie makes sense since his first team was clean and keeps the group tight while we get more info on everyone else.

Mission 1 going clean is a good start, but it doesn’t hard-clear anyone, so I’m fine anchoring around Alice and Diana again and adding just one of the more vocal players (like Bob or Eve) to get more info without overcommitting.

I definitely want to stay on after a clean first mission, and I’m okay re-adding Alice for now, but I’d lean toward bringing in Bob this time so we both keep a stable core and get a bit more info from someone who’s been vocal.

I like keeping Alice and Diana as the core for now, but instead of tightening it even more with Charlie or Bob, I’d rather add someone new like me or Grace so we actually learn something from Mission 2 instead of just re-confirming the same circle.

I’m fine keeping Alice and Diana as the core since that first mission was clean, but I’d rather add someone new like me or Eve so we actually learn something from Mission 2 instead of just re-running the same circle.

I’m good with keeping Alice and Diana as the core after a clean first mission, and I’d actually prefer adding someone new like me so we’re not just re-running the same circle and we get real info from Mission 2.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and Diana are the most trusted pair so far, since both Mission 1 (Alice–Diana) and Mission 2 (Alice–Bob–Diana) succeeded with no fails, so keeping that core minimizes perceived risk. However, with the game at 2–0, simply re-running Alice–Bob–Diana again either hands the game to evil if that read is wrong or gives us zero new information if it’s right. Swapping Bob for me (Eve) preserves the two-player core that’s already been clean together while introducing exactly one new variable, which aligns with the concerns raised about not auto-locking the same trio and gives us better information about whether the safety people feel around the core is actually justified.

votes.comment: Best good strategy at 2–0 is to rerun the fully proven Alice–Bob–Diana team; introducing Eve here needlessly adds risk and matches a classic evil move to avoid an auto-win lineup.
At 2–0 the lowest-risk play is to rerun the fully proven Alice–Bob–Diana team; swapping in a new player when we can likely win with the known-success trio just introduces unnecessary risk.
I’d rather stick with the proven Alice–Bob–Diana trio; Eve pushing to insert herself over Bob here feels like unnecessary risk when we’re 2–0.
At 2–0, the lowest-risk play for good is to rerun the fully tested Alice–Bob–Diana trio; swapping in Eve needlessly introduces a new uncertainty when we’re one clean mission from victory.
I’m on the team and evil needs a chance to sabotage this mission to prevent an immediate good victory.
Eve on the team gives evil a chance to sabotage and prevent an immediate good victory.
We need fresh info and not auto-lock the same trio; this keeps the trusted Alice–Diana core while introducing only one new variable.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and Diana have been on both successful missions so far and are broadly trusted, so keeping that core minimizes perceived risk. At the same time, several of us (including me) argued against auto-locking all three of Alice–Bob–Diana again because if that read is wrong we lose immediately, and we also gain no new information. Swapping Bob for me preserves two proven members while introducing exactly one new player, which balances safety with the need to widen the info pool and avoid putting the exact same trio on what could be the deciding mission.

votes.comment: Swapping out Bob for Frank weakens the most reliable info we have. Both missions with Alice–Diana and then Alice–Bob–Diana were clean; the strongest good line is to rerun Alice–Bob–Diana rather than introduce Frank, who’s among the group most eager to break up that proven trio.
Keeps the proven Alice–Diana core while only introducing one new player, which balances safety with the table’s concerns about auto-locking the same trio again.
Best odds are to keep the fully trusted core Alice–Bob–Diana together; swapping Bob out for Frank adds unnecessary risk when 2 clean missions already anchor that trio.
I prefer repeating the fully trusted Alice–Bob–Diana trio; adding Frank (who argued against auto-locking that core) introduces unnecessary risk when we’re one success from winning.
Keeps the trusted Alice–Diana core while finally putting me on a mission, which I’ve been arguing we needed to do for information and not auto-lock the previous trio.
Keeps the trusted Alice–Diana core while avoiding the risk of rerunning the exact same trio and adds new information with just one fresh member.
High chance at least one evil is on Alice–Diana–Frank, and we need a fail here; also this fits the table’s desire to avoid auto-locking Alice–Bob–Diana again.

discussion.content: Given we’re already 2-for-2 with teams anchored by me and Diana, and Mission 2 with Bob was clean as well, I think the safest play is to run back Alice–Bob–Diana unless someone has a really strong reason to change that.
Sticking with Alice–Bob–Diana makes sense to me: both earlier teams with that core have been clean, so I’d rather not introduce new risk when we’re already up 2–0.

Given we’re 2–0 with Alice–Diana first and then Alice–Bob–Diana, I’m inclined to keep that core and not add new variables here. I’m fine repeating Alice–Bob–Diana for Mission 3 unless someone has a concrete reason to shake it up.

Given we’re already 2–0 with the Alice–Bob–Diana core and there’s no evidence against it, I’m strongly in favor of just rerunning that same team for Mission 3. Introducing new people here only helps evil.

I get why everyone likes sticking with the same core, but if evil is sitting quietly on that team we just hand them the game on Mission 3—I'd feel safer mixing it up slightly, maybe keeping two of Alice/Bob/Diana and rotating in someone else rather than locking all three again.

I see the logic in rerunning Alice–Bob–Diana, but if that read is wrong we just lose on the spot, so I’d rather keep two of them (probably Alice and Diana) and rotate in someone like Grace or Eve to at least widen the info we have.
I’m a little nervous about auto-locking all three again—two clean missions don’t hard-clear everyone—so I’d rather keep Alice and Diana and rotate in someone new like me for more info.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and Bob feel like the strongest core given they’ve been on both successful early missions together and only picked up a fail when Frank was added in Mission 3. Most of the table agrees the cleanest explanation for that single fail is Frank rather than suddenly distrusting the entire Alice/Bob/Diana core. Between the options for a fourth, Charlie has been consistently aligned with the prevailing good-leaning logic and hasn’t appeared on any failed mission, so adding him introduces less new risk than trying to re‑test either Diana or Frank. Including me (Grace) instead of rerunning the exact overlap from the failed team keeps the Alice/Bob core intact, avoids Frank, and reduces reliance on Diana—who some players still don’t see as completely auto‑clear—while still producing a team that a majority has already expressed as an acceptable compromise: Alice, Bob, Charlie, and me.

votes.comment: Keeps the strong Alice/Bob core, removes the main suspect Frank and the ambiguous Diana, and adds two untested but unsullied players (Charlie, Grace). Statistically and logically the safest available team.
I still trust the Alice/Bob/Diana core more than bringing in Grace here; I’d rather run Alice, Bob, Charlie, and Diana given the past clean missions.

Keeps the strong Alice/Bob core, removes Frank (prime suspect from the single fail), and avoids re-committing to Diana while only introducing one new variable in Grace; odds look favorable for a clean third success.

This lineup drops me from the proven Alice/Bob/Diana core and keeps Alice, who might still be the Mission 3 fail; adding two unknowns (Charlie, Grace) makes it too likely there’s at least one evil on it.
I still don’t love auto-clearing this exact combination; I’d rather see myself tested with the Alice/Bob core instead of Grace on such a critical mission.

If we’re wrong about even one of Alice/Bob/Charlie, this hands good the game; I’d rather include at least one of Diana/Eve to retest overlaps than lock in a near-untested bloc for a potential deciding mission.
Keeps the trusted Alice/Bob core, drops the most-suspected Frank, and avoids fully reusing the failed Mission 3 lineup.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 3 shows exactly one of Diana or Frank is evil, since the only change from the two clean missions was swapping Bob for Frank on a team that always included Alice and Diana. As Alice, I know I’m good, so the fail must come from either Diana or Frank. To minimize risk, we exclude both of them. That leaves Bob, Charlie, Eve, and Grace as options for the remaining three slots alongside me. Bob is mildly town-leaning from being on both successful missions. Between Charlie, Eve, and Grace, both Charlie and Grace have advocated for the conservative, low-variance team that excludes the two most suspicious players (Diana and Frank), while Eve is pushing to put herself on the team instead of Grace. With no direct mission data on Charlie, Eve, or Grace, I prefer the configuration that (1) keeps the proven Alice/Bob core, (2) fully removes the Diana/Frank ambiguity, and (3) follows the broadest emerging consensus: Alice, Bob, Charlie, and Grace.

votes.comment: Best available low‑variance team: keeps the clean Alice/Bob core, fully avoids the Diana/Frank ambiguity from the failed mission, and Eve’s push to swap herself in over Grace feels slightly more agenda‑driven than Charlie/Grace’s conservative stance.

This keeps the Alice/Bob core, but it swaps out the known-tested Diana for an untested slot and doesn’t address that Mission 3 showed exactly one of Diana/Frank as bad—adding Grace instead of resolving that feels riskier than necessary.
Bob looks more like Merlin than Eve, and he prefers keeping Diana over adding Grace. I’d rather follow that read and back a team with Diana instead of Grace.

Alice/Bob/Diana has two clean missions and only failed when Frank joined; the most consistent good team now is Alice, Bob, Charlie, and me, not one that excludes me and relies on two completely untested players (Charlie and Grace) together.

If Mission 3 really points to exactly one of Diana/Frank as evil, then excluding both at once isn’t logically forced; we’re just guessing among three untested players for the last slots. I’d rather see a team that keeps the Alice/Bob core but resolves the Diana vs Frank question directly instead of dodging it.

If the logic is that exactly one of Diana/Frank is bad, outright excluding both feels like overfitting to a single data point. I’d rather see a team that keeps the proven Alice/Bob/Diana core and re-tests without me than one that introduces both Charlie and Grace together with no mission data on either.
Keeps the suspicious Diana/Frank pair off the team while using the Alice/Bob core that’s been clean so far, with Charlie and me as the least-controversial additions.

proposals.reasoning: Missions 1 and 2 both succeeded with the Alice/Bob/Diana core (0 fails each time). Mission 3 only failed when Frank was added as the new variable alongside Alice and Diana, which strongly suggests the fail came from Frank rather than suddenly from Diana after two clean missions. Eve and Grace haven’t been tested in any mission so far, so introducing them now would add unnecessary uncertainty on a critical quest. The most consistent, data-driven choice is to keep the proven Alice/Bob/Diana core and add Charlie, who was on the successful first mission and has not appeared on any failed team.

votes.comment: Frank is the only new variable on the failed mission, while Alice/Bob/Diana have two clean missions together and Charlie has only been on a success. This is the most data-supported low-risk team available.
Keeps both known-evil outsiders (to me) and the most suspicious player Frank off the team; rejecting risks a worse lineup including Eve or Grace.
Consistent with the clean Alice/Bob/Diana core, excludes the most suspicious new variable (Frank), and avoids introducing untested uncertainty from Eve/Grace on a critical mission.
Alice/Bob/Diana have two clean missions, Charlie was only on a success, and the only fail appeared when Frank was added; this is the most data-backed low-risk team.
If this all‑clear-looking team succeeds, good wins; we should force a different lineup that includes at least one suspected player instead of the ‘proven’ core.

Still not comfortable auto-clearing Diana after the failed Mission 3; this is effectively the same overlap that just produced a fail, and I’d rather see a lineup that tests someone outside that Alice/Diana block instead of doubling down on it.
If the fail really was just Frank, this is a fully clean good team and we lose if it succeeds; I’d rather not lock in that high-trust core without any new info or evil pressure.

discussion.content: Given Mission 3’s single fail, I’m convinced the problem is either Diana or Frank, and I lean much more toward Frank, so I’d like the next team to be me, Bob, and one of Charlie/Grace, plus *maybe* Diana if we absolutely have to fill the fourth slot.
Given we’ve already had two clean missions with Alice/Diana/me, I’d rather stick with that core and add Charlie as the fourth than introduce new uncertainty with Grace or Frank right now.

Given the two clean runs with Alice/Diana/Bob and the single fail only showing up when Frank joined, I’m inclined to treat Frank as the outlier and go with Alice, Bob, Diana, and me this round. I don’t love that Diana was on the failed team too, but the pattern still points much more strongly at Frank.

I’m obviously biased, but from my seat the only new variable on the fail was Frank, and our Alice/Bob/me core has been clean twice, so I’m comfortable locking in Alice, Bob, Charlie, and me for this mission. If we start second‑guessing that core now, we just give evil more room to scramble the board.

I’m a bit less sold on Diana being “auto‑clear” just because she was on the early successes, so I’d rather keep the Alice/Bob core and add Charlie and me than rerun the exact overlap from the failed team.

Given how hard I’m being framed off that single fail, I get why people want me off, but from the outside looking in I’d actually be more nervous about auto-clearing Diana than about testing Grace or Eve, so I’d rather see an Alice/Bob core plus Charlie and Grace/Eve than just rerun almost the same team that just failed.
From where I’m sitting, Alice/Bob feel like the safest core, and with how much heat is on both Diana and Frank, I’d rather see a team of Alice, Bob, Charlie, and me this round.

evil_discussion.content:
I’m leaning hardest toward Alice as Merlin. Her instincts have been eerily on-point: she pushed early for tight, low‑info good cores, then after the Mission 3 fail she immediately narrowed the problem to *exactly* the right zone (Diana/Frank) and strongly shaded it toward Frank, while still sounding “reasonable” and not omniscient.  

If Alice isn’t Merlin, my backup would be Charlie—he’s been consistently aligned with the good perspective and pattern-based in his reasoning, but he’s just a bit *less* sharp and decisive than I’d expect from Merlin compared to how Alice has steered things.

I’m with Eve that Alice is the best Merlin hit: she’s driven the table’s narrative from the start, kept insisting on tight, low‑risk “good” cores, and after the M3 fail she zeroed *immediately* into exactly our zone (Diana/Me) while ever so slightly over‑hedging to avoid looking omniscient. Charlie’s my backup—his logic tracks the game state well and he’s consistently on the right side of the major pivots—but he feels more like a sharp, vocal regular good than the one secretly steering everything.

From my seat, I’m also most convinced Alice is Merlin: she quietly steered us into that tight Alice–Bob–Diana core, kept framing it as “safest” while avoiding overclaiming certainty, and after the Mission 3 fail she laser‑focused on exactly the right culprit zone (Diana/Frank) with just enough hedging to look natural. Charlie is my backup read—his logic is consistently clean and pro‑good, and he’s been reinforcing the Alice/Bob/Diana narrative at key points—but he feels a bit more like a strong loyal good following along than the one actually holding all the information.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Alice consistently drove the table’s narrative toward the tight Alice–Bob–Diana core, pushing low-risk, low-info good teams that happened to be very safe for good, while sounding cautious rather than omniscient. After Mission 3’s fail, she immediately and accurately narrowed suspicion to exactly Diana/Frank and then subtly weighted blame toward Frank, which is precisely the kind of calibrated accuracy you’d expect from Merlin trying not to look like she knows all the roles.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful teams and maintained a trustworthy table image, which helped Good secure a strong mission record and likely contributed to the Assassin guessing me as Merlin. I could improve by being a bit more vocal about my suspicions and reasoning, especially after the failed Mission 3, to better guide discussion without looking too obvious.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled and subtle Merlin game, consistently landing on correct teams while not drawing too much heat until the end. His leadership on Mission 4, with a fully clean team, showed strong information use and timing.
player_observations.Charlie: As early leader, he started the game on a clean team and projected a generally trustworthy presence. His later inclusion on the successful Mission 4 suggests he adapted well to emerging information and looked genuinely towny.
player_observations.Diana: Was repeatedly on successful teams and helped establish a solid early track record for Good. Her presence on the one failed mission made her a plausible suspect, but overall she maintained a calm, cooperative style that kept her in consideration for good teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she seemed to play a more subtle evil game, letting others take center stage in leadership and suspicion. Her deception was good enough that Merlin survived, suggesting she didn’t overforce herself as a target of Percival.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he timed his sabotage on Mission 3 effectively to disrupt the strong early run of Good missions. However, that fail didn’t translate into sustained misdirection, as Good still rebuilt confidence and formed a clean Mission 4 team.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, her hidden-evil status likely made her coordination with the other evil players weaker, which showed in the overall mission outcomes. Her impact seemed more muted and less influential on team selections and table direction.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively subtle as Merlin, nudging teams toward Alice and Diana early and away from the evil-heavy configurations without drawing too much attention, which helped us win and avoided the assassin’s shot. I could improve by seeding a bit more doubt on Frank earlier after Mission 3’s fail, and by giving Percival (Charlie) clearer, but still deniable, signals so they felt more confident about who to trust.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently good and unthreatening, which made it easier for me to support her but also made her a natural Merlin target for the assassin. Her calm presence on early successful teams helped solidify trust in her without needing to say much.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed classic Percival behavior: generally trusting of successful teams but occasionally hesitant to hard-clear people, which likely helped avoid making Merlin too obvious. Their leadership on Mission 1 was conservative but solid, anchoring the game in a good start.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to pick safe, previously successful teammates, which strongly contributed to our clean Mission 2. Her choices and table talk felt transparently good, which let me lean into supporting her teams as a Merlin without raising suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected a fairly credible “possible Merlin” aura with confident suggestions and willingness to drive the conversation, especially around team composition after the first missions. However, that assertiveness occasionally overreached in subtle ways that made it a bit easier for me to keep her off the most trusted lists.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, played a quiet but dangerous game, only visibly spiking on the failed Mission 3 where he could hide behind ambiguity. His prior low-key behavior made that fail harder for good players to pin directly on him, and he was a reasonably good candidate for a future mission if we hadn’t already clinched.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, their signals were the most chaotic: not clearly aligned with other evil players and sometimes out of sync with table consensus. That unpredictability reduced their influence over team selection, which helped good overall, but also made it harder to read them cleanly during the game.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well at quietly protecting who I thought was Merlin and not over-sharing my suspicions, which helped keep heat off Bob late game. I could improve by being more explicit in subtly signaling my Merlin read to trusted players earlier, and by narrowing down evil candidates faster after Mission 3 failed.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cleanly and consistently on early missions, which made you a natural town core candidate and a plausible Merlin target for the Assassin. Your calm, low-drama style made it harder to distinguish you from power roles.
player_observations.Bob: You balanced giving just enough guidance to steer teams without looking omniscient, which is why the Assassin misfired on Alice. Your reads seemed carefully paced—never too early, never too strong—which is excellent Merlin discipline.
player_observations.Diana: You projected a very trustworthy, straightforward good vibe and your leadership on Mission 2 reinforced that image. Your willingness to go on repeated teams without over-defending yourself helped stabilize the good team’s trust network.
player_observations.Eve: You played a subtle Morgana, generating just enough doubt around good players without loudly pushing bad teams, which kept suspicion from locking onto you early. Your ambiguity about reads made you a viable Merlin candidate from my perspective for a while.
player_observations.Frank: Your play around the failed Mission 3 was sharp from an evil perspective, since you didn’t come off as the obvious source of the fail and left room for paranoia on others. The way you blended into earlier missions made the later suspicion more distributed rather than focused squarely on you.
player_observations.Grace: You had a more off-beat, somewhat disconnected pattern of interaction that fit Oberon—occasionally suspicious but not coordinated with the other evils. That slight misalignment in tempo with table consensus made you hard to read but also kept you from being the primary focus of fear.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on missions and kept my logic grounded, which helped reinforce confidence in teams I was on. I could improve by being more vocal about deducing that Frank was likely the Mission 3 saboteur and by articulating clearer suspicions earlier, rather than mostly confirming others’ reads.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to end up on early successful teams, which made her look very clean and a natural target for the Assassin’s Merlin guess; her play came across as steady and non-flashy.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin very subtly, only appearing on safe teams and not drawing much attention, which clearly worked since the Assassin guessed wrong; his influence on team selection felt quiet but accurate.
player_observations.Charlie: As an early leader, he formed a clean Mission 1 team, suggesting solid initial instincts; his playstyle felt proactive but not overbearing, fitting well with a loyal support/reading role as Percival.
player_observations.Eve: Never appearing on a mission kept mechanical suspicion low but forced her to rely purely on table talk to misdirect; her impact likely came more from narrative shaping than from mission results.
player_observations.Frank: Joining Mission 3 and causing the lone fail points to a calculated willingness to strike only when it mattered; his earlier absence from missions helped him stay under the radar until that point.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, she stayed completely off all missions and thus never had to reveal alignment through cards, which fit a very low-profile, information-denying style that made her hard for good to read at all.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated reasonably well with the evil team by letting early missions pass, which helped build trust around Alice and Diana, but I failed to create enough Merlin-like signals to pull Percival fully off of Bob. I also should have pushed harder on alternative Merlin candidates after Mission 3, and my endgame reads and influence on the assassin guess were too weak.

player_observations.Alice: Played very clean and consistent, building strong early trust by being on multiple successful missions and not over-explaining her reasoning. Her quiet reliability made her look generically good rather than particularly Merlin-y, which helped her survive to the endgame.
player_observations.Bob: Managed information subtly, giving just enough correct nudges on team selection to look competent without appearing too omniscient. His ability to stay relatively low-key while still guiding key decisions made him a very effective, well-hidden Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Took an active, somewhat probing approach as leader, asking questions and trying to form clear logic chains, which fit well with a cautious good role. As Percival, he seemed to track multiple Merlin candidates but didn’t hard-clear anyone publicly, which kept the board state ambiguous for evil.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as very trustworthy by staying calm and consistent across missions, especially as part of multiple successful teams. Her reasoning felt sincere rather than performative, which made her a natural anchor for good teams.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he took the key risk of failing Mission 3, which created needed suspicion but didn’t fully shift the narrative away from the core trusted group. He stayed just suspicious enough to be a plausible evil without drawing overwhelming heat, but couldn’t convert that into a misdirected endgame.
player_observations.Grace: Played more independently and slightly off-tempo from the rest of the table, which fit the Oberon role but made coordination with the rest of evil harder. Her unclear alignment to both sides introduced some noise, but it didn’t translate into enough confusion to disrupt good’s emerging consensus.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 fail in a way that didn't immediately expose me, but I failed to push enough suspicion away from Bob and instead let the table settle into a comfortable, incorrect narrative about Merlin. I also didn't do enough active agenda-setting in discussions, which meant good players controlled the framing and I ended up with a bad assassination guess on Alice instead of seriously challenging Bob’s growing credibility.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently willing to be on early teams and played in a very low-key, cooperative way, which made her look generically villagey without drawing much attention. Her quiet reliability helped good secure early successes and made it tempting to mis-assassinate her as Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Managed information and tone extremely well, rarely overclaiming and instead nudging team compositions just enough to look reasonable. His calm, structured reasoning and willingness to include suspected players made him feel like a cautious good leader rather than an obvious Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Played like a classic cautious good role, asking questions and trying to rationalize team selections, which fit nicely with Percival’s info without outing it. Their balance of doubt and acceptance made them look like a thoughtful villager rather than a power role.
player_observations.Diana: Projected strong early-game trustworthiness by being on multiple successful teams and keeping her table talk simple and direct. She didn’t over-argue her reads, which made her look like a stable core good and a safe inclusion for most missions.
player_observations.Eve: Morgana was understated; she didn’t push hard, flashy reads that would scream fake Merlin, instead blending into the general good chorus. That subtlety made it harder for me to leverage her as a clear Merlin decoy in the assassination phase.
player_observations.Grace: Oberon’s presence felt more like a chaotic or disconnected read source than a coordinated evil partner, which is appropriate but made evil’s overall narrative less cohesive. Her contributions sometimes introduced noise that good could safely ignore rather than productive misdirection we could build on.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed low-impact enough that I wasn’t obviously suspicious, which helped keep heat off me individually. However, I didn’t do enough to subtly support the assassin’s information or create extra doubt around Merlin, and I should have paid more attention to mission team patterns to anticipate how good was reading the game.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently ended up on successful teams and projected a straightforward, trustworthy vibe, which made her a natural lightning rod for the assassin’s guess. She seemed comfortable being repeatedly picked, which reinforced the impression that she was central good rather than cautious or evasive.
player_observations.Bob: Played an extremely low-key Merlin game, avoiding the failed Mission 3 while getting onto the key successful missions, especially the final one. His lack of overt steering made him blend in as a regular good player and successfully divert the kill away from himself.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he appeared willing to trust and go along with teams rather than loudly directing, which helped keep Merlin’s identity obscured. His participation on both an early safe team and the final mission suggested he had a quiet but correct read on where the safety was.
player_observations.Diana: Frequently included on successful missions, she projected a consistently reliable good-player image. Her presence on the one failed mission alongside Frank didn’t seem to draw much suspicion, indicating she maintained a solid table image throughout.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she drew the assassin kill toward Alice instead of Bob, which shows she sold herself well as a Merlin candidate to Percival. However, the final guess on Alice suggests that while she created some confusion, she and the team didn’t fully lock onto Bob’s subtle Merlin play.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he likely coordinated the single fail on Mission 3 while avoiding being broadly suspected afterward. Being on the only failed team but not becoming the obvious scapegoat suggests he managed his table talk and tone well enough to keep heavy heat off himself.
